title: 107_hr883
content: The Act titled "American Land Sovereignty Protection Act" is established for the purpose of protecting American land sovereignty. Congress finds that the power to regulate US lands belongs to Congress under the Constitution, some international land designations require laws enacted by Congress for implementation. Actions by the United States in designating lands may impact nearby non-Federal lands, affecting state sovereignty and private property rights. Such actions can conflict with congressional responsibilities and state capabilities. The Act aims to reaffirm Congress's authority over international agreements concerning US lands, protect State powers, and ensure no loss of individual rights due to Federal actions on designated lands. The Act aims to protect private property rights from Federal actions designating lands under international agreements. It also establishes a process for the United States to designate lands under such agreements when necessary. SEC. 3. CLARIFICATION OF CONGRESSIONAL ROLE IN WORLD HERITAGE SITE LISTING. Section 401 of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 is amended to restrict the nomination of US lands for the World Heritage List unless commercially viable uses are identified. The nomination of US lands for the World Heritage List is restricted unless certain conditions are met, including ensuring that existing uses are not adversely affected, submitting a report on natural resources and impacts, and obtaining specific authorization by law. The President may propose legislation for a nomination after a finding is published. The Secretary of the Interior must object to including US properties on the World Heritage in Danger list unless a report on necessity, natural resources, and impacts is submitted to Congress. The Secretary of the Interior must submit an annual report on each World Heritage Site in the US to Congress, detailing money spent on site management. The Secretary is authorized to agree to include properties on the list through a joint resolution of Congress. The Secretary of the Interior must provide an annual report to Congress for each US World Heritage Site, including expenditures, federal hours, NGO contributions, and complaint dispositions related to site management. SEC. 4. PROHIBITION AND TERMINATION OF UNAUTHORIZED UNITED NATIONS BIOSPHERE RESERVES. Title IV of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 prohibits Federal officials from nominating any lands in the United States as a Biosphere Reserve under the Man and Biosphere Program of UNESCO. Any existing designations as a Biosphere Reserve will not have any force unless specifically authorized by a law enacted between the date of enactment and December 31, 2003. The National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 prohibit Federal officials from nominating US lands as Biosphere Reserves under UNESCO's Man and Biosphere Program. Existing designations as Biosphere Reserves require specific authorization by law between the enactment date and December 31, 2003. The Secretary of State must submit an annual report on each US Biosphere Reserve to specified congressional committees, detailing expenditures, federal hours dedicated to management, and nongovernmental involvement. Existing designations as Biosphere Reserves require specific authorization by law between the enactment date and December 31, 2003. The Secretary of State must submit an annual report on each US Biosphere Reserve to specified congressional committees, detailing expenditures, federal hours dedicated to management, nongovernmental organizations involved, and complaints received related to reserve management. SEC. 5. INTERNATIONAL AGREEMENTS IN GENERAL. Title IV of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 is amended to require specific authorization by law for any federal official to nominate, classify, or designate lands owned by the United States for special or restricted use under international agreements. The President can propose legislation for such actions. Additionally, lands owned by a State or local government cannot be nominated, classified, or designated under international agreements unless authorized by state law. The section specifies that any nomination, classification, or designation of privately owned lands under international agreements requires written consent from the landowner. Exceptions include agreements under specific acts like the North American Wetlands Conservation Act. The term 'international agreement' encompasses various types of agreements between the US and foreign entities aimed at conservation. The curr_chunk states that an entity's primary purpose is to conserve, preserve, or protect the environment, flora, or fauna. Section 401(b) of the National Historic Preservation Act Amendments of 1980 is amended to replace "Committee on Natural Resources" with "Committee on Resources."
